description: From Middle English sap, from Old English s√¶p (‚Äújuice, sap‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *sap (‚Äúsap, juice‚Äù) (compare Dutch sap, German Saft, Icelandic safi), from Proto-Indo-European *sab-, *sap- (‚Äúto taste‚Äù) (compare Welsh syb-wydd (‚Äúfir‚Äù), Latin sapa (‚Äúmust, new wine‚Äù), Russian —Å–æÃÅ–ø–ª–∏ (s√≥pli, ‚Äúsnivel‚Äù), Old Armenian ’∞’°’¥ (ham, ‚Äútaste‚Äù), Avestan ê¨¨ê¨å-ê¨±ê¨Åê¨ûê¨Ä‚Äé (vi-≈°ƒÅpa, ‚Äúhaving poisonous juices‚Äù), Sanskrit ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç (sabar, ‚Äújuice, nectar‚Äù)). More at sage.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The juice of plants of any kind, especially the ascending and descending juices or circulating fluid essential to nutrition.
(uncountable) The sapwood, or alburnum, of a tree.
(slang, countable) A naive person; a simpleton

verbs.description: sap (third-person singular simple present saps, present participle sapping, simple past and past participle sapped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To drain, suck or absorb from (tree, etc.).
(transitive, figurative) To exhaust the vitality of.
(countable, US, slang) A short wooden club; a leather-covered hand weapon; a blackjack.
examples: I risk my whole future, the hatred of the cops and Eddie Mars' gang. I dodge bullets and eat saps.

verbs.description: sap (third-person singular simple present saps, present participle sapping, simple past and past participle sapped)

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To strike with a sap (with a blackjack).
examples: [A]s he passes the mouth of a narrow alley two men step out quickly. One of them saps Marlowe expertly ‚Äî they drag him out of sight.

description: From French saper (compare Spanish zapar and Italian zappare) from sape (‚Äúsort of scythe‚Äù), from Late Latin sappa (‚Äúsort of mattock‚Äù).

entries.meaning: (military) A narrow ditch or trench made from the foremost parallel toward the glacis or covert way of a besieged place by digging under cover of gabions, etc.

verbs.description: sap (third-person singular simple present saps, present participle sapping, simple past and past participle sapped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To subvert by digging or wearing away; to mine; to undermine; to destroy the foundation of.
(transitive) To make unstable or infirm; to unsettle; to weaken.
examples: Ring out the grief that saps the mind [‚Ä¶]

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To proceed by mining, or by secretly undermining; to execute saps.
